In the summer of 1961, we moved from my aunt’s house to our own single family home on Linden Road in the suburb of Fairmount Heights. It was big enough for our family of ten. I finally had a room to share with my second-oldest sister instead of being crammed in with four girls to a room. It was that trip to Dairy Fresh that triggered Ma’s first real act of physical aggression toward me in a long while.

Dairy Fresh was a chain of convenience stores here in Ohio. Ma was sending me to get a gallon of milk and a few other items. The milk came in glass containers with a plastic handle. My sister—the one I shared the bedroom with—begged to come along. I refused. I was always looking after one sibling or another, and I just wanted a moment of peace.

Of course, Ma had other ideas. “Take your sister with you,” she said, warning me about what would happen if I didn’t keep watch over her.

Initiation of Action involves beginning any new activity.

EF speaks to how well we manage the unexpected, the unfamiliar, the often not structured. For those of us on the spectrum, “how well” is often not very well. And though our faltering stems from real challenges within our brains, the fact is that the tax collector doesn’t really care if we let the grass go. No matter how wonderful or world-changing our ideas, to anyone looking, we seem like too intelligent, bored, self-absorbed, irresponsible people making excuses. And we will be treated as people whose respect matters to us, then we have to understand why it is that we think as we do and struggle as we do. Like it or not, until we grasp the “whys,” we won’t find effective tools to support the day-to-day tasks that must happen in order to keep a job, maintain a relationship, and feel like competent adults.

The reason we feel “so smart but so stupid” is that we are lost, confused, alone, and misunderstood in the space between our intelligence and our executive function. Whether there is a small gap or a chasm, the result is the same. We know we should know, but we don’t know what we should know or how to explain why we don’t know.

So, on behalf of all of us who really and truly are wired differently—even if we’re invisible on the Monopoly board—please trust in this: we are trying. And we’re really very good at thinking and managing information . . . in the ways that come most naturally to us. Our normal. Not yours. Respectfully, I’d assert that most neurotypicals would find themselves equally distracted, frustrated, and disappointed were they the minority living in a primarily autistic world. It doesn’t make us right and them wrong or vice versa.

It’s simple logic that we are all much more successful in life if we are encouraged to be, and, in fact, sought after for being, ourselves.

FIRST LESSONS

I was born on Christmas Day. A day some consider sacred, while most see it as a joyous, special time of year. For my mother, however, my birth was an inconvenience. How dare I ruin her holiday by making my entrance into the world! Ma was a narcissist, and her needs and desires always came first. She would make sure I felt this almost every day of my life. The little girl who wanted nothing more than to receive and give love slowly retreated into the winter of my soul.

I lived in a two-parent household. Prior to my mother joining the workforce, my father, who was given the name Daydee by my oldest brother because he couldn’t say daddy, was the sole provider. Ma was the stay-at-home wife and disciplinarian to what would become eight children. I am the eldest daughter of the brood. She was a stern, no nonsense, exacting woman. As an only child, she worked during her high school years to help her mother keep their home. Her philosophy was her way, or the highway.

We were treated like enlistees in her one-woman army, always lining up oldest to the youngest to receive our marching orders.

So how did I become the disempowered, voiceless person? It was easy. As a child, I looked up to and wanted to be like her. What young girl doesn’t want to replicate her mom in some form? She was pretty, popular and intelligent. She played the piano, and boy could she sing! The adoration I had for my mother made me ripe for the picking. My kind-hearted, trusting and loyal traits made me the prime target for her controlling, harshly opinionated and volatile ways. My mother had one specific agenda—to have me stay within her orbit. I was taught early on that my needs and desires didn’t matter. My first recollection of what my relationship with my mother was to be like was kindergarten.

It was my first day at Maplewood Elementary School. The teacher had a sandwich board with pockets covering the board. In the pockets were the names of each of the students. We were to go over, find our names and then return to our seats to practice writing them. Several of the children had plucked their names from the board and I was still standing there looking bewildered. I knew my full name and how to spell it, but only by rote.

Having never seen the alphabet or my name spelled out, I stood like a statue. I only returned to my seat, after the teacher pulled my name from the pocket that had been staring me in the face the entire time. She asked me to write my name. That was an epic fail.

A bucket of dirty mop water sat in the middle of the floor, blocking the bathroom door. I remember that bucket clear as day because I had to sidestep to get pass Ma to the toilet. So, of course, that’s the moment Ma decided to give me a directive about something she could’ve done.

"Go get the baby powder from the dresser," she said, walking right pass me.

"I’m about to pee myself," I blurted, dancing from foot to foot.

She stopped, turned back and repeated herself. "I said go get the baby powder."

The Medusa-like look she shot me should’ve frozen me in my tracks, made me run for the talc—but I was tired of being her gofer, All I wanted to do was take a piss in peace. And before I knew it, the words came flying up and out:

"Oh, shut up, bitch!" Her hand was faster than my mouth, coming down so hard that I staggered back against the bucket. Dirty water flew up to the ceiling.

Hearing all the ruckus was my brother, who was still in the bathroom while Ma scolded her.

relevant_pages.quote:
"Oh, shut up, bitch."

Her hand was faster than lightning. She back-handed me so hard that I stumbled backward, my heel catching the mop bucket. Dirty water spilling, splashing everywhere.

My feet started slipping, trying to keep me from falling on the wet floor. I flailed my arms, which only propelled me backward—and then I went down, landing in the tub that still had my brother’s bathwater in it, my feet sticking up toward the ceiling.

Hearing all the commotion, Daydee came to see what the ruckus was. He found me in the tub, soaking wet and crying, while Ma screamed, "You better get that heifer before I kill her."

Daydee hauled me out of the tub and calmed her down enough so she wouldn’t do any real harm. The water was warm, but my skin felt cold. The smell of soap and mop water clung to me as I stood there trying to make sense of what had just happened. I don’t even remember the slap itself—just the shock. That was the first time I could recall Ma striking me.

Then he asked what had made her slap me. When I told him, he wanted to know who’d taught me such a word. Daydee was calm as always. I can only remember a few times in my life when I ever saw him angry.

I rattled out my neighbor like Judas selling out Jesus for thirty pieces of silver.
relevant_pages.context: The text describes a moment of physical altercation and emotional confusion, highlighting sensations of instability, temperature contrasts, and shock in response to unexpected violence.

relevant_pages.quote:
I don’t know if I cried because I was hurt or because I was stunned, or maybe it was both. Mostly, I felt embarrassed—ashamed, even—for the way I’d fallen backward into the tub, legs in the air like some kind of cartoon.

Thinking back now, I realize how easily I could’ve hit my head on that porcelain edge. But Ma didn’t seem concern. I was six then. That was a time when teaching me better ways to express myself should’ve been at the forefront of my mother’s mind. But when a person has narcissistic tendencies, it becomes more about them and their feelings.

I had challenged her authority and rejected the role she had set for me. The hurt and betrayal cut deep—not just physically, but emotionally. I was devastated by the actions of both my mother and my neighbor, who’d had the tar whipped out of him for his part in it.

He apologized to me and to Ma, but things were never the same between us again. That slap became her go-to form of punishment for me—one good crack across the face with her hand, a shoe, or whatever was handy.

That fateful day, she drew the proverbial line in the sand, daring me to cross it. But even after that episode, I still wanted her love. I learned to bend myself into whatever shape pleased her—more accommodating, more careful, Quieter. Anything to avoid her wrath.

Chapter 3:

THE GIFT BECAME THE CHORE

It was Christmastime, and we were visiting my great-aunt Edna, Uncle Bruce, and my cousins. The adults sat around talking about their plans for the holidays when Ma mentioned how I had ruined her Christmas by being born on the holiday. Everyone laughed—except her. When the laughter died down, my aunt turned to me and asked what I wanted for Christmas.

I hesitated before saying, “A drink and wet doll.”

Aunt Edna’s face lit up. She went on and on about how much fun I’d have with that doll, and her excitement got me so hyped I dreamed about it every night until Christmas morning.

When the day finally came, I rushed to the tree, searching for a box with my name on it. There was no doll. In fact, there was no present for me at all. I sat on the floor watching everyone else open their gifts, mustering my best happy-for-you face. I was already getting good at hiding disappointment.

A little while later, Ma told me to follow her to the kitchen. My heart jumped—I was sure the doll was waiting for me in there, all wrapped up and sitting at my place at the table. But

when I walked in, I saw the ironing board. Ma never ironed on Sundays or holidays, so that was strange in itself. She led me to the narrow end of the flatbed, and sitting next to her board was a child-sized ironing board with a fully functional toy iron. Rarely did I receive more than one gift acknowledging the holiday and my birthday, so I began looking around for the doll.

"What are you looking for?" she asked.

"The drink and wet doll," I said.

"That's your present," she replied, pointing to the board and iron.

My heart sank. Ma told me it was better than a doll because now I could learn to iron the small clothing items for the family—handkerchiefs, underwear, and such. For the next two years, I did just that.

By eight, I had "graduated" to washing clothes with our wringer washing machine. Wash day was an all-day affair: sorting, rinsing in a separate tub, sending each piece through the wringer, then hanging the load outside while the next batch was washed.

Saturdays became laundry days, Sundays were for church, and just like that, my weekends disappeared. I had no say or choice in how I wanted to spend my free time.

The summer I was nine, a small fire broke out at the house. It started in the front closet where Daydee kept his blowtorch. We all knew not to touch it for any reason, but with three

relevant_pages.quote:
mischievous brothers around…well anything was bound to happen. It was only a matter of time before curiosity struck a match. Thick smoke filled the air—the closet held all our coats, boots, and a few fur pieces that belonged to my aunt. The flames licked up toward the staircase that led to the apartment above us. Ma rushed upstairs to warn the neighbors.

The smoke poured from the front part of upstairs. Smoke billowed out of the two small windows in our apartment, curling like gray ghosts. I was terrified. Our relationship might have been rocky, but she was still my mother. And I loved her.

Somehow Ma made it back downstairs and out into the yard, coughing and sputtering. The boy from next door—the same one who’d once gotten me in trouble—had called the fire department and was standing beside me asking if there was anything he could do. I told him to get her some water. We sat on his stoop until the firefighters put out the flames.

When it was safe to go back inside, Daydee started questioning everyone. He swore to whip each child old enough to “know better” with his razor strap. The only ones spared were the baby—and me. I had an ironclad alibi. I’d been doing laundry.

Ma, still weak and nauseous from the smoke, went to rest while my great-aunt made her tea and soup. What I didn’t know then was that Ma was pregnant. Wanting to show her I could take care of her, I carried the tray into her room and stayed with her, tending to her every need.

That’s how it began.

relevant_pages.quote:
I became the "dutiful daughter" mindlessly going along with her every whim—believing that if I was good enough, helpful enough, maybe she’d finally love me.

In the kitchen, there was a wooden crate that Ma used to reach the upper shelves. She found another use for it soon enough, Homework, dinner, dishes, bed—rinse and repeat. That’s right, along with doing the laundry, I’d been given the added duty of washing the dishes every night.

I’d stand on the box, my arms practically up to my elbows in soap suds, scrubbing away at plates and pots. Fortunately for me, we ate a lot of one-pot meals. Ma wasn’t anybody’s cook. Every now and then, Daydee would take pity and cook for us. When he did, he’d wash the pots himself so I wouldn’t have to.

Aunt Johnnie, on the other hand, cooked big Sunday dinners. I loved helping her set the dining room table with her fine china. Occasionally, she’d let me help her cook, teaching me the basics—how to season, stir, and taste. I loved those moments with her.

But somehow, Ma always found a way to break them up. Just when I’d start enjoying myself, she’d call me for some unnecessary chore, and like clockwork, I’d go—obedient, quiet, careful. Ma didn’t want to spend time with me herself, but she didn’t want anyone else to have those moments with me either. It was all about control.

The child’s ironing board was supposed to be a gift, but it was really my introduction to servitude. What started as a Christmas present turned into a training tool—a way to mold me into Ma’s.

She used the iron and that little board to teach me how to serve her needs, not to build my own skills. What she didn’t enjoy doing became my responsibility. Ironing, dishes, laundry—it all slid quietly from her plate onto mine. There was a strange kind of pride in doing things right. If I ironed a shirt without a wrinkle or folded a stack of laundry just so, I might get a nod of approval. That tiny scrap of recognition felt like love, or close enough to keep me chasing it.

But behind that approval was control. Ma’s version of love came with strings—and the knots tightened a little more each year. The more I helped her, the more she expected. And when she realized she could depend on me to take care of her, she made sure I never forgot it.

Looking back now, I see that was the moment she began shaping me into an extension of herself. Not a daughter, not even a child—just a reflection of her moods, her wants, her weariness. And I learned early that in her world, the line between helping and disappearing was paper thin.

Chapter 4:
A HARD KNOCK LIFE

In the summer of 1961, we moved from my aunt’s house to our own single family home on Linden Road in the suburb of Fairmount Heights. It was big enough for our family of ten. I finally had a room to share with my second-oldest sister instead of being crammed in with four girls to a room. The neighborhood was quiet and diverse, with a gas station on the corner, a mom-and-pop store on the next block, and the school with a Dairy Fresh Deli nearby. It was that trip to Dairy Fresh that triggered Ma’s first real act of physical aggression toward me in a long while.

Dairy Fresh was a chain of convenience stores here in Ohio. Ma was sending me to get a gallon of milk and a few other items. The milk came in glass containers with a plastic handle. My sister—the one I shared the bedroom with—begged to come along. I refused. I was always looking after one sibling or another, and I just wanted a moment of peace.

Of course, Ma had other ideas. “Take your sister with you,” she said, warning me about what would happen if I didn’t keep watch over her.
